import React from 'react'; import './Notes.css'; const PracticalGeometryNotes: React.FC = () => { return (

Chapter 10: Practical Geometry

Introduction to Practical Geometry

Practical geometry deals with the construction of geometric figures using basic tools like a ruler (straightedge), compass, protractor, and set squares. This chapter focuses on constructing lines and various types of triangles based on given measurements and properties.

Did You Know?

Euclidean geometry, on which practical geometry is based, has been studied for over two millennia and is still fundamental to many fields of science and engineering.

Construction of a Line Parallel to a Given Line

We can construct a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line using the property of alternate interior angles or corresponding angles.

Method (using corresponding angles):

  1. Draw a line 'l' and take a point 'A' outside 'l'.
  2. Take any point 'B' on 'l' and join A to B.
  3. With B as center and a convenient radius, draw an arc cutting 'l' at C and AB at D.
  4. With A as center and the same radius, draw an arc EF cutting AB at G.
  5. Place the compass pointer at C and open it to the length CD.
  6. With G as center and the same radius, draw an arc cutting the arc EF at H.
  7. Join AH and extend it to form line 'm'. Line 'm' is parallel to line 'l'.

Construction of Triangles

We can construct a unique triangle if we are given certain combinations of its sides and angles. The conditions for constructing a unique triangle are:

  • SSS (Side-Side-Side) Criterion: When the lengths of all three sides are given.
  • SAS (Side-Angle-Side) Criterion: When the lengths of two sides and the measure of the included angle are given.
  • ASA (Angle-Side-Angle) Criterion: When the measures of two angles and the length of the included side are given.
  • RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side) Criterion: When the length of the hypotenuse and one side of a right-angled triangle are given.

Example (SSS Construction):

Construct a triangle ABC where AB = 5 cm, BC = 6 cm, and AC = 7 cm.

  1. Draw a line segment BC of length 6 cm.
  2. With B as center, draw an arc of radius 5 cm.
  3. With C as center, draw an arc of radius 7 cm, intersecting the previous arc at point A.
  4. Join AB and AC. Triangle ABC is the required triangle.

Summary

  • Practical geometry involves constructing figures using ruler and compass.
  • Parallel lines can be constructed using angle properties.
  • Unique triangles can be constructed using SSS, SAS, ASA, or RHS criteria.
); }; export default PracticalGeometryNotes;
